title: THEATER;When Comedians Meet, It's Not All Laughs
description: EVERY stand-up comic is gunning for a spot on the Buddy King television show. Comedy writers would put each other away to get on staff. Don't talk about what agents would do.

title: Baymen's Tools: Variety and Tradition
description: BILLY SCHULTZ of East Hampton is one of a score or so of baymen who make their livings on the inland waters of the East End. After being discharged from the Army in 1958, he tried cattle ranching and dairy farming. But since 1962, he has fished.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;2 New River Tours For Rhode Island
description: This summer and fall, visitors to Rhode Island may choose between two new river tours that explore the urban geography and history of the state.

title: WEDDINGS;Fran D. Goldman, Robert C. Fink
description: Fran Debra Goldman, the daughter of Ellen and Joel Goldman of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to Robert Cary Fink, a son of Lorraine and George Fink of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Freedman performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Erika G. Henik, Joel H. Tranter
description: Erika Gail Henik, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Willy Henik of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married today to Joel Hillson Tranter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Revan Tranter of Berkeley, Calif. Rabbi Meyer Rabinowitz is to officiate at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton.

title: Frugal Choices
description: To the Editor: Regarding your recent article by Susan Spano, "Penny-Wise in Paris: Right Bank Choices" (June 5), it was a lesson on where not to stay in Paris.

title: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE ADVOCATES;Many Health Groups Fight House Democratic Leaders' Plan
description: A broad assortment of doctors, hospitals, private insurance companies, health maintenance organizations, state officials and big employers said today that they disliked a central element of the House Democratic leaders' health plan, which would more than double the size of the Federal Medicare program.

title: Connecticut Q & A: David Gelenter;To Think Is Indeed to Dream. Maybe.
description: MOST of the research into building computers that think the way humans do has focused on logic and has largely ignored more emotional and creative thinking.

title: THAT SCITEX GLOW
description: For several years I worked for a large firm that has all the Scitex equipment; the retouching effects it could produce never ceased to impress me (Style: "That Scitex Glow," by Mary Tannen, July 10). I often said (not jokingly) that for my 40th birthday, I'd treat myself to a good studio portrait and some aggressive Scitex touch ups. I'd wind up with a photo of my ideal face: larger eyes, longer lashes, real cheekbones, baby-soft skin and a blank stare.

title: WEDDINGS;Delores T. Benn, William Inzerillo
description: Delores T. Benn, a daughter of Delores and John Benn of Commack, L.I., is to be married today to William Inzerillo, a son of Marie and Biagio Inzerillo, also of Commack. Dr. David Harmon, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Long Island, is to officiate at Riverview, a restaurant in Oakdale, L.I.

title: FILM;Sometimes, Three Is the Loneliest Number
description: IN "IT COULD HAPPEN TO YOU," a police officer named Charlie (Nicolas Cage) stares deeply into the eyes of a waitress named Yvonne (Bridget Fonda) with the conviction of a man who has just tuned in to the frequency of true love. Charlie and his wife, Muriel (Rosie Perez), have just won millions in the New York lottery.

title: WEDDINGS;Maureen Holland, Timothy Dibble
description: Maureen Therese Holland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Holland of Hingham, Mass., was married there yesterday to Timothy Lavern Dibble, the son of Ursula Dibble of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Prof. Vernon K. Dibble. Deacon Edward Doyle officiated at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

title: WEDDINGS;Colleen C. Coyle, Craig J. Fecke
description: Colleen Clare Coyle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Coyle of Flushing, Queens, was married there yesterday to Craig James Fecke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fecke of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Matthew J. Diamond performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Andrew Avellino Church. Msgr. John Keough, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents 30 years ago, took part in the ceremony.

title: Montecatini
description: To the Editor: William Weaver's "Taking the Waters in Tuscany," while comprehensive, made this exquisite town sound more like an infirmary than a spa. I don't think it is true, even for Italians, that most visitors come to improve their health. Most of the people we saw were clearly on holiday. For my mother, my sister and me, a visit in 1992 was a joyful celebration of Mother's 80th birthday.

title: This Week's Numbers
description: Last Consensus Period Estimates (I.D.E.A. INC.)

title: HORSE RACING;Caution for N.Y.R.A.: Even at Saratoga Spa, the Well Can Run Dry
description: Maybe they should have listened to Horatio Luro, the late, great trainer, who always warned horse people: "Don't squeeze the lemon dry."

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Farrell And Mr. Fox
description: Anne Marie Farrell, a daughter of Pauline A. Farrell of Oswego, N.Y., and the late James E. Farrell Sr., was married yesterday to George Patrick Fox 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fox Jr. of Old Field, L.I. Msgr. Francis J. Furfaro performed the ceremony at the Sage Chapel at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Political Lunacy
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORRIS HEIGHTS;Short on Services, Neighborhood Sees New Use for Old Building
description: Shelby Dickson sat on a bench beside a basketball court littered with broken glass, next to an abandoned lot overgrown with weeds and strewn with garbage. Peering across Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, she looked at a four-story, white-brick building whose graffiti-covered facade incorporates two Stars of David and texts from the Talmud.

title: Where the Talk Is of Dogs and Sheep
description: I TOLD me wife," the Irish farmer said, "that if she'd let me away for the sheep dog trials, she could holiday wherever she wished, to the ends of the earth. At first she thought she'd go up to Dublin, some pricey hotel, but she began to worry about those 'muggers' so she holidayed at the seaside resort we usually go to, not much brass, quite near our home. A good deal for me, yes?"

title: P. A. Meiselman, Bertrand Boulet
description: Pamela Abbe Meiselman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Meiselman of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Bertrand Boulet, the son of Claudine Boulet of Conflans-Ste.-Honorine, France, and the late Bernard Boulet. Town Justice Katherine Cahill of East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the summer house of the bride's parents in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: OUT OF ORDER;Seeing Straight to the Heart of the Matter
description: WHEN I was a child, people often remarked on the dreamy, faraway look in my eyes.

title: No to National Police
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Develops Incentive to Reduce Time in Foster Care
description: Seeking to reduce the time children spend in foster care, New York State is developing a new approach that would financially reward nonprofit agencies that quickly return children home or place them for adoption -- and penalize agencies that move slowly.

title: SURFACING
description: MOTION Speed board: Fans of the Powell long board, which is more than a foot longer than the average skateboard, say it's faster and easier to handle. But tricks are not so easy.

title: Festival Teaching Jazz to Students
description: WHEN Giacomo DiGrigoli signed up for a four-week choral jazz program this summer, he was motivated by curiosity.

title: Runways;The Suit Rebounds, Tailored to Leisure
description: Just when you thought it was safe to abandon the suit (at least on Fridays), men's fashion is sharpening up. The revenge of the tailored suit on sloppy sportswear was the story at the European men's wear shows in early July.

title: We Are How We Eat
description: THE HUNGRY SOUL Eating and the Perfecting of Our Nature. By Leon R. Kass. Illustrated. 248 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95. PARENTS who have tried to socialize toddlers at the dinner table will probably agree with one of Leon R. Kass's arguments: skillful eating makes for more pleasant mealtimes. His larger theme -- that refined table manners actually increase our moral stature -- is not so easily digested.

title: The Conversion of Fawaz Turki
description: EXILE'S RETURN The Making of a Palestinian American. By Fawaz Turki. 274 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95. FAWAZ TURKI has written two previous books about his life in the Palestinian diaspora, "The Disinherited: Journal of a Palestinian Exile" (1972) and "Soul in Exile: Lives of a Palestinian Revolutionary" (1988). In his latest book, "Exile's Return," Mr. Turki goes back to Haifa holding, not a Kalashnikov, but an American passport. Now it is the passport rather than the struggle that gives his life its meaning.

title: Cape Cod, Seen Through Field Glasses
description: CAPE COD has a way of turning birding skeptics into enthusiasts. Through most of the year, I am only a now-and-then birder (the term is preferred to bird watcher by the cognoscenti), satisfied to scrutinize the species that visit my feeder or fly across my path. Yet even before I cross the Sagamore or Bourne Bridge over the Cape Cod Canal, I am already scanning the skies and salt marshes of southeastern Massachusetts for the first harbingers of the birding bonanza to come.

title: THE NIGHT;Tennis, Telethon, Cello: So Many Things to Play
description: UPTOWN -- David N. Dinkins was wearing a beautifully tailored pin-stripe suit at the post-screening party for "It Could Happen to You" on Tuesday at the Central Park Boathouse. He was looking as much the Mayor as ever.

title: Caring for the Elderly and Children, Too
description: EIGHTEEN months ago Zoe Ward and her husband, Edward, invited Mrs. Ward's 84-year-old mother to live with them in the Stratford home they share with their two young children. The older woman's short-term memory was failing as a result of Alzheimer's disease, and she could no longer live alone, Mrs. Ward said.

title: The View From: Orange;A Candy Factory Where Nostalgia's Sweet
description: REMEMBER Pez? The cute little candy dispenser with a head that lifts back (Popeye or Santa Claus or whoever) to dispense a tiny piece of candy? Lots of people had them in the 50's and 60's, and they are still around, dozens and dozens of brightly painted models of favorite cartoon characters like the Peanuts gang, the Flintstones and Sesame Street. Pez has become a classic candy, and the company, based in Orange, helps keep things that way by using classic characters to dispense the strawberry, grape, orange and lemon candies.

title: Profile;The Job, Thankless; the Challenge, Huge. Let's Go.
description: FORTUNATELY, Jeffrey C. Barbakow likes challenges, because he recently faced the challenge of a lifetime.

title: Trump Joins Davids I. Suitors
description: DAVIDS ISLAND, once an active Army post guarding New York from attack by sea, now sits abandoned off the coastline here -- considered by many to be prime real estate. Not used since World War I, the 120-acre site on Long Island Sound periodically catches the fancy of developers, who see high-rise dwellings there, and city fathers, who would like the property to generate revenue for New Rochelle's declining tax base.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pirates May Be Going Up for Sale
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates' board of directors, expected to vote Wednesday on a new stadium lease, may instead put the team up for sale. The Pirates notified major league baseball's ownership committee they were discussing a sale to one of two groups. (AP)

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Places Where Women Made History
description: As tourist attractions go, 142 West Fourth Street in Cincinnati, is pretty subtle. But the furniture store and garage visitors see today occupy the site where Lucy Hobbs Taylor, the nation's first female dentist, learned to drill and fill teeth in the early 1860's. Though the place lacks a commemorative plaque, it is immortalized on page 356 of a hefty new book, "Susan B. Anthony Slept Here: A Guide to American Women's Landmarks" by Lynn Sherr and Jurate Kazickas (Times Books, $18).

title: Crossing the River: The Israel-Jordan Pact -- A special report.;Amid Debt, Doubt and Secrecy, Hussein and Rabin Made Peace
description: On the evening of May 19 in a quiet London living room, two war horses of the Middle East -- men who were present at the creation of the conflict between their countries nearly half a century ago -- met secretly to end it once and for all.

title: Corrections
description: Three pictures on July 24 with an article about Malden Mills, a Massachusetts textile maker, were published in error. The workers pictured, David Austin and Lori Morrison, are employees of Wickers Sportswear in Wolfeboro, N.H., not Malden Mills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 30 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the new Davis Museum and Cultural Center at Wellesley College refers incorrectly to the donation that gave the museum its name. It was a gift, not a bequest, from Kathryn Wasserman Davis and her husband, Shelby Cullom Davis.

title: A Cozy Base in the Wild Highlands
description: A TIDY seaside resort with amusement arcades and a deluxe golf course, a white sweep of curving beach, and a small, snug yacht harbor, all not far from a New Age spiritual center: This was not exactly how I'd envisioned the wild and rugged Scottish Highlands. When my husband, James, and I turned onto High Street in Nairn, a town of 10,000 just 15 miles east of Inverness on the Moray Firth, it seemed almost too civilized.

title: Graduate's Speech Brings Effort to Have Harvard Bar Him
description: A high school administrator here has tried to punish a Harvard-bound student who strayed from his written remarks in a graduation speech, prompting the school board to consider a more liberal speech code.

title: BASEBALL;Ohioans to Clinton: Stop Strike
description: President Clinton got an earful today from baseball fans in Ohio who urged him to head off a threatened major league strike. He was sympathetic, but made no promises.

title: Viewpoints;High Tech Needs 'MacNeil/Lehrer,' Too
description: EYEING the promise of vast profits from the information superhighway, many telecommunications companies oppose Federal efforts to increase the presence of noncommercial information services in this new technology. But, in order to enrich the superhighway's offerings and to be faithful to our traditions, this resistance must be overcome.

title: WEDDINGS;Lee A. Rolontz Ernest R. Fritz
description: Lee Alison Rolontz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rolontz of New York, was married on Fire Island yesterday to Ernest Raphael Fritz, a son of Eugenia B. Fritz of Laurel, Md., and the late Capt. Ernest S. Fritz. The Rev. Dr. Paul W. Zeckhausen 3d, a United Church of Christ minister who had officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's-by-the-Sea in Saltaire, L.I.

title: WEDDINGS;Kathleen Flatley, Robert O. G. Ix
description: Kathleen Dolora Flatley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Flatley of Boston, was married yesterday to Robert Owens Gilmore Ix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Ix of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Daniel McLeod, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth Seton Church in North Falmouth, Mass.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12

title: THE FIRST LADY'S NEW CLOTHES
description: In her On Washington column "The First Lady's New Clothes" (July 10), Maureen Dowd writes that "Mrs. Clinton has tried to capture some of the Jackie glamour." No way. Hillary Rodham Clinton never tries to imitate anyone. She's an original, as was that other First Lady, Jacqueline Kennedy.

title: A Career Made of Being Where He Doesn't Belong
description: Dan Penn IS PROPPED against a graffiti-covered wall in Harlem. The photographer motions to him and Mr. Penn responds by pushing his sunglasses down and popping a toothpick into his mouth. He's locked in an expression somewhere between small-town hood and big-city cool. Just then a car comes around the corner, and a passenger leans out the window and yells, "Go home, whiteys!" Hearing that, Mr. Penn smiles slightly, his toothpick shifting upward.

title: Surfers Can Now Seek the Perfect Wave at Deal
description: THE thousands of dedicated surfers who descend on the Jersey Shore each weekend, searching for the perfect wave, can now seek that ultimate experience in Deal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: ON LANGUAGE;Java Jive
description: When life was much simpler, coffee was just coffee (milk and sugar being optional) and a bar was a bar (you know, where they serve liquor). Now that nothing is simple and establishments known as coffee bars have spawned a caffe latte culture, replete with literary journals, you are supposed to know the various kinds of coffee concoctions, what to call them and how to order them.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORDHAM;Campaign for the Paradise Tries to Save the Inside, Too
description: For two years, community leaders have pushed for landmark status for the exterior of the old Loew's Paradise, the ornate 65-year-old movie palace that has enchanted generations of Bronx residents.

title: July 24-30;A Desert Blooms; Now It's a Park
description: For at least 15 years, Congress has recognized that the California desert needed protection from the encroachment of humankind. The explosive population growth in the nation's biggest state was threatening one of the world's rarest ecosystems.

title: S. L. Williams, 61; Led Bar Association
description: Samuel L. Williams, a lawyer who turned down a seat on the California Supreme Court to become the first black president of the State Bar of California, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 61 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;The Curse of Incessant Cursing
description: JOE TORRY DANCES HIS WAY TO CENTER stage, dressed in a white T-shirt, black leather vest and black pants, to welcome his theater and television audience to "Russell Simmons's Def Comedy Jam." Five minutes later, he completes the routine, which is largely about his feelings that the women in the audience should have more active sex lives. In the process, he uses at least 63 words considered unprintable here. That's one profane or vulgar term every 4.7 seconds.

title: Oregon Jury Convicts Man in 4 Killings Linked to Hell's Angels
description: A man who prosecutors say was under orders from a top Hell's Angels leader was convicted today of murdering a woman, her twin 6-year-old girls and a family friend 17 years ago.

title: ABOUT SPAM
description: For those who wish to know more about Spam's impact ("More Than You Wanted to Know About Spam," by Judith Stone, July 3), I submit an addendum:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST RIVER;F.D.R. Work Spells the End Of Easy Parking For 500 Drivers
description: Some 500 parking spaces have disappeared under the F.D.R. Drive and they won't be returning soon, if ever.

title: The Executive Life;A Summer Boot Camp For Budding Executives
description: WHILE her friends went to field hockey camp, baby-sat or worked as lifeguards this summer, Kacie Croson, 16, spent millions of dollars -- much of it borrowed -- in a struggle to turn a fledgling computer company into a profitable venture.

title: THING;Soldier, 30, Seeks Comeback
description: WHAT A commemorative replica of the original G.I. Joe, introduced in 1964 by Hasbro Inc. and the most popular "action figure" in toy industry history, with 250 million sold to date. The 30th-anniversary figure will be available in August in five versions: one each from the Air Force, the Marine Corps and the Navy and two from the Army (one white soldier and one black).

title: Throwaway Plastic Bottles and the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Years Later, an Arrest in a Manhattan Doctor's Slaying
description: Nearly 13 years ago, Dr. John Chase Wood Jr., a 31-year-old resident in surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, was accosted by three young men as he strode back to the hospital from dinner at home nearby with his pregnant wife.

title: Exxon Was Right. Alas.
description: Five years after the Exxon Valdez spill, the oil company is paying its final bills for the destruction its tanker caused in Prince William Sound.

title: The Nation;New Role for Presidents Cuts 2 Ways on Health
description: WHEN Congress considered Medicare in 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson had made the bill a major priority, and he was continually involved in twisting arms to get it passed. Yet his name rarely appeared in newspaper or television accounts of its progress on Capitol Hill.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Fewer Tours For the Disabled
description: WE are an endangered species," said Barbara Jacobson of Flying Wheels Travel in Owatonna, Minn., a travel agency-tour operator that since 1970 has specialized in travel for wheelchair users.

title: A Beautiful Example of Older Workers' Value
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Tonality Is Dead; Long Live Tonality
description: IN PRAGUE AFTER THE VELVET REVOLUTION, IT was easy to get lost on familiar streets. Names were changed overnight: Lenin Avenue became Europe Avenue. The Gottwald metro station, named for the dark overlord of the Czechoslovak Communist revolution, was rechristened Vysehrad, after the noble rock featured in Smetana's "Ma Vlast." A similar process has been going on in American academic music departments in the last decade, as the ideology of Serialism has lost its stranglehold.

title: NOTICED;Sweating, Then Strutting
description: AT Chanel's recent haute-couture show in Paris, the designer Karl Lagerfeld showed a body-binding corsetlike bustier as the basic element to be paired with his current variation on the classic Chanel suit.

title: WEDDINGS;Kristin Kovach, F. L. Hohmann 3d
description: Kristin Lyn Kovach, a model with Wilhemina Models in New York, was married yesterday to Frank L. Hohmann 3d, a managing director of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment bank in New York. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones officiated at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: The Case for the Cold War
description: THE COLD WAR A History. By Martin Walker. 392 pp. New York: A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt & Company. $30.

title: World Markets;In Mexico, a Case of Political Jitters
description: UNCERTAINTY is getting to be an unwelcome economic fixture here. Last week offered a mirror image of last year. Through most of 1993, Mexico's stock exchange and money market were whipsawed by the changing fortunes of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Frugal Choices
description: To the Editor: Susan Spano seems to enjoy carrying her suitcase all over town while looking for a suitable low-cost hotel. Wouldn't she have done better by taking a package trip?

title: Straus Park Needs More Than Just a Facelift
description: To the Editor:

title: HERE NOW;East of the Bowery, Music Gets a Room
description: AS New York's answer to Bourbon Street, Avenue A and most of its adjoining side streets offer a cornucopia of saloon culture. A thirsty body can find neighborhood bars; tourist bars; bars that play live country music, punk rock or jazz; bars with drag shows; biker bars; straight and gay bars; one bar made up like a baby's playpen, and another that looks like a jail.

title: HORSE RACING;Alex the Great Conquers Saratoga
description: Alex the Great, a 5-year-old horse bred in England and raced mainly in France and California, brought his traveling act to Saratoga today and outran stars such as Fraise and Sea Hero to win the $250,000 Sword Dancer Handicap. Fraise, the Breeders' Cup champion, finished fourth; Sea Hero, the winner of last year's Kentucky Derby, ran seventh in Saratoga's foremost grass race.

title: There Are Solutions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 17 about the New York Stage and Film Company misspelled the name of the author of the play "Amazing Frogs and Toads." She is Terri Minsky, not Terry Linsky. A schedule listing with the article misspelled the surname of the author of "The Quilling of Prue," a work in progress. She is Mary Gail, not Gall.

title: Credit Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Sonoma County
description: To the Editor: As East Coast residents and long-term devotees of Timberhill Ranch in northern Sonoma County, Calif., we were dismayed to read Lynn Freed's review of that haven, "Seeing the Pacific's Wilder Side" (June 26).

title: ON WASHINGTON;Sic Transit Agnew
description: Not much goes on in Tryon, N.C.

title: Latin Nations at U.N. Delay Resolution on Haiti Invasion
description: Latin American and Caribbean nations are delaying United Nations approval of the Clinton Administration's proposal for the possible invasion of Haiti if sanctions fail to remove the military Government from power.

title: July 24-30: Health Triumph Undercut;Lead Levels Still High Among Many Poor Children
description: After lead additives were phased out of gasoline between 1976 and 1991, the average amount of lead circulating in the bloodstreams of Americans plummeted by 78 percent, a government study has found. Health officials last week hailed the finding as a major public health triumph.

title: Signs Of Life In County's Economy
description: NEWS this month that I.B.M. profits jumped during the second quarter of the year appeared to signal more than just a fresh start for the once-beleaguered Armonk-based computer giant. Analysts said the announcement from the county's largest private employer ended weeks of speculation that the economy in general in Westchester was finally pulling out of a slump.

title: PERSPECTIVES;On a Fashionable Avenue, an Old-Fashioned Style
description: THE number 654 has followed N. Anthony Rolfe around for more than 50 years, he says. He was assigned to an LST bearing that number as a young naval officer in 1943, and he served on it for three years.

title: Sex and Stones
description: SHEAR By Tim Parks. 211 pp. New York: Grove Press. $21. THERE is something irresistible about characters in fiction who complicate their lives through sexual adventure. We may laugh at their duplicity and divided attention, yet we often admire their daring. Their situation serves as both a wish fulfillment and a warning.

title: BASEBALL;Durocher's Teams Never Did Defeat Rizzuto's Yanks
description: He too reached the major leagues as a shortstop with the Yankees, and for him, the wait for Cooperstown was every bit as long as Phil Rizzuto's. But when Leo Durocher is inducted posthumously into the Baseball Hall of Fame this afternoon, it will be for his ability to call the shots correctly from the dugout, not for fielding them adeptly from his position.

title: WEDDINGS;Darcy W. Dunn, Mark A. Singer
description: Darcy Wynne Dunn, the daughter of Doris Dunn of New York and Warren E. Dunn of Morris Plains, N.J., was married on Thursday to Mark Aryeh Singer, a son of Judith and Isadore Singer of Passaic, N.J. Rabbi Simcha Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: WEDDINGS;Emily S. Jonas, Patrick J. Trotti 3d
description: Emily Susan Jonas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manfred Jonas of Schenectady, N.Y., is to be married today to Patrick John Trotti 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Trotti Jr. of Tarrytown, N.Y. Donald J. McGrath, a marriage officer of the Town of Philipstown, N.Y., is to officiate at Hudson House, an inn in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Diets Make You Fatter, and for Good Reasons;Kale, Kasha and Quinoa
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina Detains 3 in Bombing That Killed 100
description: Following a trail of parking lot tickets and auto repair bills, the police have detained three Buenos Aires men suspected of preparing the truck bomb that killed about 100 people here last week.

title: Archer Sets Her Sights For the National Team
description: MARGARET ADLER has her eye on a certain jacket, and it isn't available at any shopping malls. The red, white and blue item is worn by members of an elite team sponsored by the Junior Olympic Archery Development program of the National Archery Association, and judging by the progress Maggie has made in her two years as an archer, the team is within her grasp.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Walter D. Berkowitz;Fighting a Potent Enemy: Heart Attacks
description: A PERSON experiencing sudden chest pain has one hour to get to a hospital to have it diagnosed and treated. Longer than that, and the person risks dying of a heart attack.

title: ABOUT MEN;Coloring Lessons
description: It was the big annual fair at Shady Hill, a private school nestled away in one of our city's finer neighborhoods. Though October, it was warm and the ash gray clouds were giving way to soft, swelling shapes of blue. There were lots of kids already, their parents working the various concessions -- apple bobbing and doughnut biting, water-balloon throwing at a heckling buffoon -- all ploys to harvest money for the school's scholarship fund.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa Rosenthal, Michael Mittleman
description: Lisa Jan Rosenthal, a daughter of Marjorie P. Rosenthal of New York, is to be married today to Michael Jay Mittleman, a son of Linda and Richard Mittleman of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Shira Stern is to officiate at the Stanhope Hotel in New York.

title: Surgeon Helps Feed Hungry
description: INSIDE the van, organized frenzy prevailed. Five adults bustling at the tailgate packed sandwiches, pastries and apples into plastic bags, then handed them to the crowd outside. At the door opposite the driver's seat, two adults and a 3-year-old boy distributed chocolate candies, cups of iced tea and cups of peach slices.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 20 of the Times Magazine today about President Clinton's political career misstates the timing of his resignation as Governor of Arkansas. Mr. Clinton resigned in December 1992, after he was elected President; he did not resign to seek the Presidency.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;An Unlikely Jets Pair Cross Paths in Pursuit of Their N.F.L. Kicking Dream
description: When did their dreams begin?

title: WEDDINGS;Ahn Y. Lee and Jay McKechnie
description: Ahn Yuet Lee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stimson Lee of New York, and Joseph Roy McKechnie Jr., the son of Sheila Saunders of New York and Mr. McKechnie of Toronto, were married yesterday in New York. Judge William Mogulescu of New York City Criminal Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the New York Palace.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Mexico Moves to Limit Projects Along Its Coast
description: AFTER 20 years of favoring big developments like Cancun that gobble up miles of coastline and pave over thousands of acres of sensitive wetlands, the Mexican Government is trying to switch directions and limit what can be built on the beach.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 31, 1994
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: PRO FOOTBALL;It's Tears and Touchdowns At Canton's Hall of Fame
description: The neat, warm and inviting homes tucked around each corner near the Pro Football Hall of Fame were decorated this afternoon in red, white and blue streamers with banners and ribbons aplenty. Fans filled the streets as this football-crazed town celebrated its annual shining moment -- the induction ceremonies reserved for only the greatest to ever play the game.

title: 60's Heroes Keep On Keeping On
description: ONLY the most tuned-out members of the baby boom generation can claim never to have heard of Mary Travers. After all, she's part of Peter, Paul and Mary, a trio that the Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock and Roll calls "the most popular acoustic folk music group of the 1960's." During that decade they produced 11 albums, 5 of which became million sellers. And they scored 12 hit singles, including the classic children's song, "Puff, the Magic Dragon" and "Leaving on a Jet Plane," a ballad written by John Denver.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Impresario of the Night
description: IT WAS 2 A.M., prime time at Limelight, and as usual the only person not dancing or ogling, drinking or gabbing, kissing or groping, was the nightclub's owner, Peter Gatien. Laser lights and house music were lashing the bodies around him, but he stood nearly motionless for minutes at a time, somberly stroking his chin as if he were eyeing a sculpture at the Met.

title: A Swim Across the Sound to Aid Cancer Fight
description: FOUR years ago, when he was 8 years old, Daniel Sibio of Thornwood was given a diagnosis of cancer. On Aug. 6, 12-year-old old Daniel, whose cancer is now in remission, and his 40-year-old father, Anthony, will swim as a relay team across Long Island Sound from Sands Point, L.I., to Larchmont. Daniel will do about one and a half miles; then he will board a boat and his father will cover the rest of the four-mile stretch of water -- all to raise money for cancer research.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: How-To Books of the Americans
description: SCIENCE AND THE SECRETS OF NATURE Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture. By William Eamon. Illustrated. 490 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $49.50.

title: Nothing Like a Visit From a Tenrec
description: THIS has been a red letter day for me," George Rovere said. "I always wanted to touch a Madagascar hissing cockroach before I died!"

title: Facing Complaints of Bias, Farrakhan Speaks to Women Only
description: Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam minister who angered many women when he barred them from attending a speech here last winter, returned on Wednesday night and delivered a speech that only women could attend.

title: Conscience & Courage'
description: To the Editor:

title: Skirmish on Welfare Plan Highlights the Chasm Between Right and Left
description: Congress concluded its first round of welfare skirmishing this week, ending four days of hearings in which members rained insults on each other, their witnesses and President Clinton's proposal to overhaul the system.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne E. Marshall And Basil A. Hero
description: Anne Elizabeth Marshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn V. Marshall of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Basil A. Hero, a son of Drs. Angela C. and Byron A. Hero of New York. Msgr. Edward Connors performed the ceremony at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

title: By Any Other Name, It Would Sound Sweeter
description: THE BIGGEST PROBLEM IS THE NAME. NO one, but no one, likes the term New Age. It's out of date, reeking of 70's tacky lava-lamp spirituality. We're so much more sophisticated and culturally aware than that now. (Aren't we?) Whatever gleam of genuine, sterling hope the words New Age may once have had has tarnished badly. There seems to be an alloy of cynicism there. Did we ever really mean it?

title: WHY DO CATHOLICS STAY IN THE CHURCH? BECAUSE OF THE STORIES
description: Father Greeley has firmly established his point that the benevolent imagery of Catholicism is paramount in the decision of many adherents to remain faithful.

title: A Deficit Revisited
description: He came into office promising to be the Mayor who finally seized control of New York City's finances. And in his first budget, he closed a $2.3 billion gap, cut spending by $1.1 billion and pared 15,000 municipal jobs.

title: Trade Talks Reach Impasse
description: The United States will formally charge Japan with failing to open its markets to telecommunications and medical equipment, an official said after talks broke off. Page 5.

title: WEDDINGS;Cecily D. Garrity, Matthew I. Janger
description: Cecily Doran Garrity, a daughter of Thomas J. Garrity of Bailey, Colo., and the late Ann M. Garrity, was married yesterday to Matthew Isaac Janger, a son of Allen and Inez Janger of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Scott Morrow, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at Capt. R. Slanders' House, an inn in Chilmark, Mass.

title: July 24-30: Extremism in Florida;Abortion Doctor And Bodyguard Killed
description: Every Friday, workers and volunteers at the Pensacola Ladies Center would escort the visiting doctor and patients past half a dozen or more shouting anti-abortion demonstrators. But last Friday a gunman killed Dr. John B. Britton, 69, and a security escort, James H. Barrett, 74, and wounded Mr. Barrett's 68-year-old wife, June.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Jordan Finally Gets First Home Run
description: Former National Basketball Association great MICHAEL JORDAN hit his first home run as a pro last night and added a run-scoring double as he helped the Birmingham Barons to a 6-1 victory over the visiting Carolina Mudcats in a Class AA Southern League game. Jordan's eighth-inning homer, a solo shot, came in his 354th at-bat and increased his average to .189.

title: A LA CARTE;Home of the Sloppy Joe (With a Difference)
description: ASK someone in Ohio or Nevada what a sloppy Joe is, and the answer will probably be that school lunch standby -- a bun topped with a mixture of ground beef and tomato sauce. But put the same question to former residents of northern New Jersey, and they get misty eyed.

title: BASEBALL;Too Small to Play, Right Size for Hall
description: Phil Rizzuto was driven to Ebbets Field in his Uncle Mike's car -- "one of those old cars, with the balloon tires," Rizzuto recalled. And he carried in a little bag with his glove his Richmond Hill High School baseball uniform. It was 1936, Rizzuto was 18 years old, and he was going for a tryout with the Dodgers, the team he loved, having grown up at Dill Place and 78th Road in Brooklyn, now a part of Queens.

title: Business Diary: July 25-29
description: COMPANIES

title: The New Deal at American Express
description: IMAGINE Tiffany's admitting that most of its customers don't need gold necklaces and would look just as elegant in beads. Or that Saks reacted to flagging couture sales by opening a discount warehouse.

title: Robin Goldberg, Michael Psaros
description: Robin Elissa Goldberg, a daughter of Melvin and Joan Goldberg of Edgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael George Psaros, a son of George and Mary Ann Psaros. The Rev. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Safeguards For L.I. Sound Due in Pact
description: AFTER nine years of study New York State, Connecticut and the Federal Government are preparing to sign a plan to set policy into the next century for restoring Long Island Sound. The far-reaching conservation and management plan could potentially cost more than $7 billion.

title: Brewers Expo Slakes Quaffers' Quality Quest
description: A GENIAL iconoclasm filled the County Center here last weekend as more than 700 beer drinkers threw off the shackles of mass-produced brews to savor the products of 70 small producers.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Artistry, an Artistic Director Learns, Is Only the Half of It
description: FROM THE EVIDENCE AT hand last month, it would have been difficult to tell that the Frankfurt Opera, one of the biggest and proudest companies in Germany, was near collapse, riven by a bitter internal feud and crippled by a 25 percent cut in public subsidies over the next four years. Or, indeed, that the entire publicly supported theater system in Germany, which had provided for spoken, musical and dance theater with unequaled lavishness, was in a profound crisis, with politicians slashing budgets and theater administrators wringing their hands in self-doubt.

title: SPECTATOR SPORT
description: Dinosaurs are not extinct. At least one is alive and well and romping through the pages of The American Spectator. After all, who but a dinosaur would write essays praising alcohol, tobacco and fatty foods?

title: Self-Management By a Co-op Board
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Revival Houses: And Then There Was One
description: You had only to go to the movies to know that the late 1970's and early 80's were the halcyon days of the revival houses. There, at the opening of "Annie Hall," was Woody Allen in his halcyon days, in line for "The Sorrow and thePity" at the Thalia. There were at least a half-dozen others then - cool, dark variations on film-buff paradise. It's all been downhill since, though. One by one - with the coming of videos and the big theater chains - the old theaters have closed or gone first-run. (Some others opened, but they, too, didn't last). And today, one of two survivors, Theater 80 on St. Marks Place, will run its last picture show, leaving only Film Forum 2 among commercial revival houses. (Several cultural institutions still show old movies in repertory.) Here is a look at the ebb and flow (but mostly ebb) of a cultural artifact.

title: Commercial Property: Helmsley-Spear;For Helmsley's Flagship, a Sense of Drift
description: As soon as Leona Helmsley was released from a halfway house in January, the talk in the commercial real-estate world was of the devastating impact she was expected to have on Helmsley-Spear, the management/ brokerage/leasing arm of Harry B. Helmsley's vast empire.

title: Heroic Measures
description: The noble sandwich is the epicurean leitmotif of summer. Baseball and the beach, picnics and idle afternoons are predicated on mobile, hand-held meals, meals of infinite variety as well as reassuring familiarity. Though the Earl of Sandwich is credited with inventing the snack between the bread, his creation reaches its apogee in America, where it continues to evolve thanks to the recent proliferation of some very fine baking.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;Art That Turns Television Frogs Into Princes
description: ALTHOUGH ARTISTS IN THIS century have made diligent efforts to introduce the most derelict items into the court of art, you might have thought television was too thoroughly masscult, too yahoo, too committed to the froggy life for any number of kisses to turn it into a prince. You would have been mistaken.

title: Mutual Funds;More Investors Like Bundled Funds
description: WHAT'S the best way to describe a mutual fund industry with nearly 5,000 funds: "diverse" or "confusing"?

title: July 24-30;Serbs Test International Resolve
description: The Serbs last week tightened the noose around Sarajevo again, cutting off the one land route out and firing at both United Nations planes and a convoy of British soldiers. But their squeeze was as much on the United States and its partners in the quest for a Bosnian peace as it was on the weary citizens of the Bosnian capital.

title: Beneath the Very British Exteriors
description: SECRET LIVES Three Novellas. By Tom Wakefield, Patrick Gale and Francis King. 254 pp. New York: Serpent's Tail. Paper, $12.99.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIRST STORIES GETTING OVER TOM By Abigail Thomas. Algonquin, $16.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Michael R. Carey and Kristen C. Watts
description: Kristen Cass Watts, the daughter of Mrs. Elkins Bruce of New Baltimore, Mich., and Dr. John Watts of La Jolla, Calif., was married yesterday to Michael Raymond Carey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J. The Rev. James Wysocki performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Cathedral in Saginaw, Mich.

title: WEDDINGS;Lucia Paolicelli, Salvatore Fratantaro
description: Dr. Lucia Marie Paolicelli, a daughter of Emanuel Paolicelli of Bayside, Queens, and the late Dorothy Paolicelli, was married yesterday to Dr. Salvatore Nicola Fratantaro, the son of Salvatore and Adeline Fratantaro of Centerdale, R.I. The Rev. Dr. John Davis performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: 2 Ambiguous Paths Converge in Killings
description: Paul Jennings Hill "simply carried out his own theology," a friend said of the man arrested on Friday in the killing of a doctor who performed abortions at a clinic in Pensacola, Fla.

title: Interstate Commerce Commission Comes Under Siege in Congress
description: The 107-year-old Interstate Commerce Commission is coming under siege in Congress, but an unusual alliance principally made up of the businesses under its supervision is fighting to rescue the agency.

title: A Sweetness Tempers South's Bitter Past
description: Black and white, they squeezed into the 150 seats in the refinished oak pews, stirring the air with hand-held fans, courtesy of the local funeral home. As more people filed in, they took up all the space along the freshly painted white walls, and then spilled into the aisles, into the new kitchen behind the pulpit, into the foyer and finally into the steamy air outside the Spring Hill Free Will Baptist Church.

title: Sonoma County
description: To the Editor: It is a joy to return home to find The New York Times on the doorstep; it is tantalizing to skim through my favorite sections in anticipation of what I'll be reading with my morning coffee. Ah-ha, another well-deserved accolade for Timberhill Ranch. What a shock to read Lynn Freed's article; this reporter doesn't seem to be reviewing the same Timberhill I know and love.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: POP-MUSIC BIOGRAPHY RHINESTONE COWBOY An Autobiography. By Glen Campbell with Tom Carter. Villard, $22.

title: FILM;Le Grand Exces Spices Love Poems to Food
description: FROM THE OPENING SEQUENCE of "Eat Drink Man Woman," it's apparent that food is not just an accessory in the film. It's a pivotal character, as seductive and provocative as the three women for whom it is continually being cooked.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Shorehams;Welcome Retirement from the Limelight
description: SINCE their inception, the hilly village of Shoreham and the unincorporated hamlet of East Shoreham on the North Shore of Long Island have taken a certain amount of pride in their obscurity.

title: Word for Word: The Condemned;As Executions Mount, So Do Infamous Last Words
description: HARDLY a week goes by in the United States without, if not another execution, some new reflection of Americans' willingness to get tough on crime by putting killers to death: a Federal crime bill expanding the number of capital offenses; Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, the icon of American liberalism, tempering his opposition to the death penalty in a tough re-election campaign; Stephen G. Breyer, the Supreme Court nominee, being grilled by Senators before satisfying them of his acceptance of the constitutionality of executions.

title: A Critic as Solitary as Kafka
description: THE CORRESPONDENCE OF WALTER BENJAMIN, 1910-1940 Edited by Gershom Scholem and Theodor W. Adorno. Translated by Manfred R. Jacobson and Evelyn M. Jacobson. 651 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $45.

title: SUNDAY, July 31, 1994;Manhole Mandalas: A Necessary Art
description: Since the 1840's, foundries have produced manhole covers for city streets. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, designers created myriad cover patterns -- Victorian, Art Nouveau, Art Deco -- that are still in use but often bear little or no information about their origins. A few designers' names are known; the cover at top left was designed in 1922 by Edwin H. Ford of the Ford Meter Box Company, in Wabash, Ind. These covers were stolen so often from New Orleans streets that a plainer one had to be introduced.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Between the Food Lines: Feuding Over Homeless Aid
description: For five years, homeless people would gather inside the old St. Agnes School at 152 East 44th Street for the stew, milk, bread and fruit delivered every night by the Coalition for the Homeless. But last Tuesday, they waited in drizzling rain behind Grand Central Terminal. When the coalition's van arrived, they ate in the open.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Mad All Over, and Cool When It Counts
description: Jim Abbott, usually calm and cool, was livid. He stood in the corner of the Yankee dugout and shouted at plate umpire Ed Hickox after he left the game in the sixth inning. Paul O'Neill, rarely calm and cool, was also livid. He slammed his helmet into the dirt after center fielder Kenny Lofton swiped a potential hit in the eighth with a gorgeous diving catch.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 31, 1994
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: Officer Charged in Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer was arrested and suspended yesterday for shooting at an empty car after a traffic dispute with its owner, the police said.

title: TRUE LIES';Dressed For Heroism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Father-and-Son Scull Circumnavigate L.I.
description: GEORGE AND JEREMY LINZEE know first-hand about many of the problems documented in the Long Island Sound Study by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. When the Linzees, father and son, circumnavigated the Island last summer, their 18-foot double scull bumped against pollution from boaters and parking lots, and they saw extreme examples of erosion, including houses falling into the water on the North Shore.

title: CUTTINGS: THIS WEEK;Sow Seeds, and Don't Forget to Pinch and Cut
description: Sow seeds of pansies and violas in a shady seed bed or cold frame. It's last call to sow forget-me-nots and English daisies. The small seedlings can be transplanted to permanent homes in late August or early September.

title: Wildwood Journal;Where Parades Enliven The Spirit of the Shore
description: AS the noon whistle resounded over the surf in Wildwood, Diego Tabbachino, the grand marshal of the New Jersey State Elks parade, held aloft his gold wand, signaling the stepoff. Trombones picked up the beat, majorettes strutted, floats rolled and clowns cavorted. American flags were everywhere.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: PRO FOOTBALL;After Wearing Out Hometown Welcome, George Flees to New Niche
description: There are more than 1,600 players in the National Football League and each yearns for his own slice of respect and adulation -- especially from his peers. Often, the players' perceptions of one another are shaped from afar.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE VILLAGES;Forget Woodstock. Whither Wigstock?
description: The East Village's trademark Labor Day drag festival, Wigstock, is looking for a new home -- in the West Village.

title: After Carjacking Surge, Puerto Rico Is Wary Behind the Wheel
description: Whenever she goes out now, Nellie Pena pulls her long hair up in a bun and takes off her earrings. The windows of her 1983 Camaro have been tinted dark.

title: Montecatini
description: To the Editor: Your article "Taking the Waters in Tuscany" (June 19) states that most visitors to Montecatini in Tuscany thrive on idleness coupled with immersion in mineral springs and baths. As an aside, the small minority of otherwise sedentary visitors take day excursions to such tourist destinations as Pisa or Florence.

title: WHY DO CATHOLICS STAY IN THE CHURCH? BECAUSE OF THE STORIES
description: What is it with numbers people? The world can turn upside down and yet they point to some figures and say nothing has happened. The latest example is Father Greeley's report that the Catholic Church is stable because "the Catholic defection rate has remained constant over 30 years. It was 15 percent in 1960 and it is 15 percent today."

title: DINING OUT;Unusual Pacific Rim Inspirations in Rye
description: DINERS in the Rye area have already found this find of a little restaurant. They come for the quality ingredients, inventive cooking and seasoning that often presents a challenge to the taste buds. And for us, therein lies a bit of a problem. It is easy to succumb to these tempting dishes full of unusual and winning combinations, which are described in detail on the small menu. One wants them all, and some are truly superb. But be warned that Peter Johnson, the chef and owner, uses hot chilies unstintingly, and although we recognize that they are essential to the "warm climate cuisines" he espouses and that peppery heat provides dishes with an additional dimension, one we usually enjoy, we're less impressed when that fire masks the flavors that led us to ordering the complex dishes in the first place.

title: Love, War and Leotards
description: MATERIALISM Poems. By Jorie Graham. 146 pp. Hopewell, N.J.: The Ecco Press. $22.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;Bookshelf
description: AROUND THE WORLD IN A HUNDRED YEARS: From Henry the Navigator to Magellan. By Jean Fritz. Illustrated by Anthony Bacon Venti. Putnam. $17.95. (Ages 7 to 11) Here is a prequel of sorts to the author's much-loved children's books on American history -- engagingly written profiles of some of the European men who explored what they called the Unknown. Illustrations and maps.

title: Custody Case Stirs Debate on Bias Against Working Women
description: A Michigan judge's decision to take a child away from a mother who placed her in day care has created a furor over whether courts are biased against working mothers and has rekindled debate about the broad leeway judges have in deciding what is in the best interests of a child.

title: WHY I SPIED;Aldrich Ames
description: RICK AMES, A LIFELONG employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, betrayed at least 12 of the best secret agents working for the United States from within the Soviet Union and the Soviet bloc during the 1980's. All were jailed and most were executed. "They died because this warped, murdering traitor wanted a bigger house and a Jaguar," says the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey.

title: Editorial Notebook;U.N. Troops Cannot Stop Genocide
description: What can the world do when hundreds of thousands of innocent civilians are slaughtered because of their race, religion, class or tribe? It happened this year in Rwanda and is still happening in Bosnia. Recently, it has happened in Cambodia, Indonesia and the Kurdish areas of Iraq.

title: WHY DO CATHOLICS STAY IN THE CHURCH? BECAUSE OF THE STORIES
description: In "Why Do Catholics Stay in the Church? Because of the Stories" (July 10), Andrew M. Greeley hits the mark. As we have moved away from the format of catechism questions and answers, storytelling from the pulpit -- the story that explains and gets to the point in under 10 minutes -- is what distinguishes a good preacher.

title: Manager's Profile
description: Douglas H. Johnson

title: U.S and Japan Break Off Trade Negotiations
description: The United States will formally charge Japan with failing to open its Government markets to American telecommunications and medical equipment products after last-minute trade talks today failed to break a negotiating log jam, a United States official said.

title: WEDDINGS;Lynn Schmeidler and Gregg M. Ury
description: Lynn Schmeidler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Schmeidler of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married today to Gregg Marc Ury, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gustav Ury of Baltimore. Rabbi Amy Bardack is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford, N.Y.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHEAST QUEENS;Immigration Jail Faces Neighborhood Battle as Its Lease Runs Out
description: Five years ago, the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service turned the two-story brown brick warehouse at 145-55 226th Street into a 100-bed detention center without warning the residents of the tranquil neighborhoods around it, Springfield Gardens and Rosedale.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS;Balancing Act: When Play and Parking Clash
description: Like hundreds of organizers who oversee Police Athletic League play streets across the city each summer, Diana Peterson is well acquainted with the difficulties: enlisting neighborhood support, keeping troublemakers away, cleaning it all up every night when the children go home.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORRISANIA;After 6 Deaths, Rally Prompts Traffic Change
description: The timing of lights on a strip of Webster Avenue in Morrisania has been changed to slow down traffic after residents of the Borgia Butler Houses rallied last week to protest the sixth pedestrian fatality in as many years on their block.

title: For a Widow, Years Rebuilding Life
description: Diana Newton Wood, whose world was all but destroyed by the bullet that killed her husband nearly 13 years ago, yesterday recalled the terrible days of trauma and the twilight years of struggle that followed, years of rebuilding her life and raising the son born five months after that fateful night.

title: Scotland's Summer Gardens
description: SETTING out from New York last July, when the temperature seemed stuck at a stifling 101, my husband, Michael, and I planned eight days in Scotland around museums, castles and gardens -- particularly gardens. In cool Scotland, gardens are at their peak in summer, and the deep greens of the landscape -- as startlingly green as Ireland's -- the fresh skies and unpressured pace were totally restorative.

title: WEDDINGS;Martha Foote, Joseph Burke Jr.
description: Martha Foote, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Foote of Seneca Falls, N.Y., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Joseph Patrick Burke Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke Sr. of Oceanside, Calif. The Rev. Peter Crego, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: NJN and Its Role Throughout the State
description: Re: "NJN Girding for Battle of Survival," July 17:

title: WESTERN NATIONS TO ADD SANCTIONS AFTER SERBS BALK
description: The United States, Russia and the European Union agreed today to seek fresh economic sanctions against Serbia in reprisal for the Bosnian Serbs' rejection of their peace plan last week. But apparently wary of risking their own fragile unity, the powers shied away from tougher measures like a renewed threat of NATO air strikes.

description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Karen A. Zelman, Kevin Dinowitz
description: Karen Aliza Zelman, the daughter of Shirley Groman Zelman and Dr. Marvin Zelman, both of West Hartford, Conn., is to be married there today to Dr. Kevin Dinowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Neal Dinowitz of Bellmore, L.I. Rabbi Alan Ullman is to officiate at Beth El Temple.

description: THERAPY THERAPY GONE MAD The True Story of Hundreds of Patients and a Generation Betrayed. By Carol Lynn Mithers. Addison-Wesley, $23.
